title: Protocol to analyze endogenous translesion DNA synthesis in single mammalian cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
TLS induction by DNA damaging agents
Timing: 30 min–5 h
Include positive TLS controls, such as UV-C irradiation or treating cells with H2O2.
For UV-C irradiation, expose cells to 15–30 J/m2 of UV-C light using an irradiator and release them in normal culture conditions (37°C, 5% CO2) for 5 h prior to harvesting.
For H2O2 treatment, add a final concentration of 1 mM H2O2 to the cell culture media for 30 min (37°C, 5% CO2) before harvesting.
Pre-extraction and fixation
Timing: 1 h
Following TLS-inducing treatments, harvest cells (on coverslips for IF or trypsinization for flow cytometry).
Always include negative controls (untreated cells and treated cells that will not be incubated with primary antibodies).
Rinse cells with ice-cold PBS.
Immunofluorescence.
Gently transfer coverslips in a 12-well plate containing 1 mL PBS on ice.
Aspirate the PBS from the corner of the wells, keep on ice.
Flow cytometry (from this point on, process the samples in 1.5 mL tubes).
Centrifuge cells at 400 × g for 3 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend cells in 1 mL ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge cells 400 × g for 3 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Pre-extraction of the cytosolic compartment using the appropriate buffer (see Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).

Immunofluorescence.
Very gently pipet 1 mL of ice-cold extraction buffer to the edge of wells.
Incubate coverslips for 3–5 min on ice (depending on the cell line used, see troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Discard extraction buffer and rinse cells once with PBS 1 mg/mL BSA solution.
Gently aspirate buffer from the edge of the wells on ice. Avoid moving the plate and proceed to the fixation (step 3.a.i/ii) within a minute.
Flow cytometry.
Resuspend cells in 100 μL of ice-cold extraction buffer by pipetting up and down 5–10 times.

Incubate cells on ice for 5–10 min (depending on cell line, see troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]).
Add 1 mL of PBS-BSA 1 mg/mL to stop the extraction.
Centrifuge 500 × g for 3 min at 4°C and carefully remove the supernatant.

Fixation of the extracted nuclei using the appropriate fixative (see Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
Immunofluorescence (proceed with i. or ii here below).
For FA fixation: gently pipet 1 mL of PBS-2% FA to the edge of wells and incubate (30 min, at 20°C–23°C).
For methanol fixation: gently pipet 1 mL of −20°C pre-chilled PBS 90% methanol to the edge of the wells, close the plate and incubate immediately at −20°C for 10 min. Avoid shaking the plate while moving it.
Remove the fixation buffer and gently rinse coverslips with 1 mL of 1× Perm/Wash (P/W) buffer.
Critical: For immunofluorescence, avoid shaking the plates before cells get fixed by FA or methanol. Determine the optimal duration of the pre-extraction step by monitoring cells under a microscope (100×) every minute. A too long incubation will result in cell dissociation from coverslips. Optimal extraction point is reached when only the nuclei remain visible under the microscope (100×). Optimal duration for HCT116 and HEK293 cells is 3–5min on ice. Representative images of unextracted vs extracted cells are shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1].
Flow cytometry (proceed with i. or ii here below).
For FA fixation: gently resuspend the extracted cell pellet in 100 μL of PBS-2% FA and incubate 30 min at 20°C–23°C.

For methanol fixation: add 100 μL of PBS-90% methanol (pre-chilled to −20°C) dropwise on the extracted pellet in a pre-chilled −20°C block, homogenize very gently the cell solution by pipetting up and down 3 times maximum and incubate for 10 min at −20°C.
Add 1 mL of ice-cold 1× P/W buffer, centrifuge the fixed nuclei 750× g for 3 min at 4°C. Carefully remove the supernatant.
Pause point: although a direct processing through the immunodetection should be preferred, cells can be stored for a maximum of 2 days in 1× P/W buffer at 4°C.
Note: The pre-extraction buffer can be completed with proteases and phosphates inhibitors and replace a classical “CSK buffer” to achieve a chromatin/soluble fractionation for western blot analysis in the same conditions than IF and flow cytometry. In this case, histones (chromatin) and alpha/beta-tubulin (cytoplasm) should be used as fractionation controls. Typically, we achieved even higher purity of fractions (chromatin/soluble proteins) while using this extraction buffer rather than classical, sucrose-based “CSK buffers”.
Immunodetection of target proteins
Timing: 4 h–16 h
In this step, endogenous TLS components will be immunodetected using highly specific, validated, commercial antibodies. Although it is preferable to perform the primary antibody incubation 16 h at 4°C, it is possible to shorten this step to 1h at 20°C–23°C, therefore allowing a fast – single working day – processing of samples from cell culture to the analysis steps.
Primary antibodies.
Immunofluorescence.
Block samples with 1 mL of 1× P/W for 1 h at 20°C–23°C.
Put the coverslips (cells side up) onto a parafilm in a humid chamber and gently pipet a drop of 50 μL of 1× P/W buffer containing the appropriate dilution of primary antibody (see Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
Incubate 16 hours at 4°C or 1 h at 20°C–23°C in a humid chamber.
Flow cytometry

Block samples in 100 μL of 1× P/W at 20°C–23°C.
Add 1 mL of 1× P/W and centrifuge at 750 × g for 5 min at 20°C–23°C.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 50 μL of 1× P/W buffer containing the appropriate dilution of primary antibody (see Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
Incubate at 16 hours 4°C, or 1 h at 20°C–23°C on a rotating wheel.
Pause point: The incubation with primary antibodies being most efficient 16 hours at 4°C, this step represents a convenient pause point. However, it is still possible to shorten this step to 1h at 20°C–23°C to process through the whole workflow in a single working day.
Secondary antibodies.
Immunofluorescence.
Gently aspirate the drop of primary antibody and wash (3 × 5 min) with 100 μL of 1× P/W buffer.
Put the coverslips (cells side up) onto a parafilm in a humid chamber and gently pipet a drop of 50 μL of 1× P/W buffer containing the appropriate dilution of Alexa Fluor-conjugated secondary antibody (see Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
Incubate 1 h at 20°C–23°C in a humid chamber, protected from light.
Flow cytometry
Add 1 mL of 1× P/W buffer, centrifuge at 750 × g for 5 min at 20°C–23°C and remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 50 μL of 1× P/W buffer containing the appropriate dilution of Alexa Fluor-conjugated secondary antibody (see Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
Incubate 1 h at 20°C–23°C on a rotating wheel, protected from light.
DNA staining and sample preparation.
Immunofluorescence.
Gently aspirate the drop containing the antibody and wash (3 × 5 min) with 100 μL of 1× P/W buffer.
Gently pipet 100 μL of PBS containing 2 μg/mL of DAPI onto the coverslips.
Incubate 10 min at 20°C–23°C, protected from light.

Gently aspirate the drop and rinse 3 times for 1 min with 100 μL of PBS.
Rinse the coverslips once in dH2O to remove the residual PBS salts.
Mount coverslips in 4–5 μL of Prolong Gold AntiFade mounting medium.
Let the mounting medium solidify 16 h at 20°C–23°C. Placing the slides at 37°C for 2–3 h will speed up the reaction without a noticeable impact on the subsequent imaging.
Flow cytometry
Add 1 mL of 1× P/W buffer, centrifuge at 750 × g for 5 min and remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 300 μL of analysis buffer (PBS-1 mg/mL BSA containing 1 μg/mL DAPI and 100 μg/mL RNAse A).
Incubate 16 hours at 4°C or 30 min at 37°C before analyzing the samples.
Sample analysis
Sample analysis.
Immunofluorescence.
Observe with a fluorescence microscope equipped with ApoTome or an equivalent option.
Set the exposure time by scanning through your positive control slide (i.e., UV-C-treated cells). The signal spectrum should never saturate in order to have a reliable quantification of the fluorescence intensities.
Save images and quantify using Image J or CellProfiler 4.2.1 software using the DAPI to make a nuclear mask. Pipelines for fully-automated nuclear foci counting, as well as intensities and colocalization of 2 or 3 targets are available upon request (and see Egger et al., Cell Reports methods, in press).
Flow cytometry.
Run the sample through a cytometer equipped with laser lines matching your antibodies and DNA counterstaining settings. In our experience, the best cytometer in terms of resolution and coefficient of variation (CV) for this kind of experiments is the Gallios.
Plot Forward Scatter (FSC) and Side Scatter (SSC) to gate in the cell population and gate out putative debris (see Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Plot DAPI Height/DAPI Area to gate in the singlets and gate out putative doublets (see Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Set the voltages for the TLS targets using your negative (no primary antibody) and positive controls (i.e., UV-C-treated cells). These settings should never be changed afterward, between the different experimental conditions.
Analyze at least 20,000 events per sample to obtain robust statistics.
Process the data with Kaluza Analysis or Flow Jow software.
